relationships.description: Fog droplets are detected as particles by light-scattering PM sensors, causing measurement overestimation
relationships.mechanism: Fog droplets are liquid aerosols that scatter light similarly to solid particles. Light-scattering PM sensors cannot distinguish between fog droplets and actual PM particles, leading to false positive readings.

normalized.interpretation: Fog presence required - either supersaturation or visible fog

normalized.note: This condition applies to sensor hardware, not environmental variables

relationships.source_quote: The gaseous humidity did not cause errors in the PM measurements via the light-scattering method. In contrast, steam humidity, such as that caused by fog, resulted in errors in the PM measurement.

quantitative_evidence.description: PM concentrations increased linearly with RH below 70% in steam humidity tests

relationships.notes: This is a measurement artifact, not actual pollution increase. Critical for data quality assessment.

relationships.description: High RH causes hygroscopic particle growth, leading to sensor overestimation of PM2.5
relationships.mechanism: At very high RH (>85%), hygroscopic particles absorb water and grow in size, increasing their light-scattering cross-section. This causes light-scattering sensors to overestimate PM mass concentrations.

normalized.interpretation: High humidity threshold for significant hygroscopic growth

relationships.source_quote: The sensor showed a high sensitivity to humidity, with the measured PM2.5 mass concentration increasing by a factor of 2-3 at RH > 85%.

quantitative_evidence.description: Sensor overestimation increases significantly at RH > 75%

relationships.notes: Overestimation factor varies with particle hygroscopicity

relationships.description: Fog provides aqueous-phase environment for rapid SO2 oxidation
relationships.mechanism: Fog droplets provide high liquid water content (LWC) environment where SO2 dissolves and is rapidly oxidized by NO2, HONO, H2O2, and O3. The high pH (>5.5) from elevated ammonia enables fast aqueous-phase oxidation.

normalized.interpretation: Minimum liquid water content for aqueous-phase reactions
High pH enables fast NO2-driven SO2 oxidation pathway
Sufficient SO2 precursor for sulfate formation

normalized.note: At least one oxidant must be present

relationships.source_quote: Fog and cloud readily form under winter haze conditions, leading to high liquid water contents with high pH (>5.5) from elevated ammonia. Such conditions enable fast aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 by NO2.

quantitative_evidence.description: Sulfate production rate in cloud water can reach 0.5-1.3 μg m⁻³ h⁻¹

relationships.notes: This is actual chemistry, not measurement artifact. Produces real PM2.5 increase.

relationships.description: Aqueous-phase oxidation produces secondary inorganic aerosols (sulfate, nitrate)
relationships.mechanism: Rapid aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 produces sulfate, while similar processes convert NOx to nitrate. These secondary inorganic aerosols (SIA) contribute significantly to PM2.5 mass.

normalized.note: All three precursors needed for complete SIA formation

conditions.original_text: fog droplets, cloud water, aerosol liquid water

normalized.interpretation: Aqueous environment required - fog, cloud, or ALW

relationships.source_quote: The synergistic effect between nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxide in the aqueous phase of aerosol particles can explain the rapid sulfate formation during severe haze events.

quantitative_evidence.description: Transformation rates of sulfate and nitrate aerosols increase by 48% and 11% respectively

relationships.description: Secondary inorganic aerosols directly contribute to PM2.5 mass
relationships.mechanism: Secondary inorganic aerosols (sulfate, nitrate, ammonium) directly contribute to PM2.5 mass. These hygroscopic species also promote further water uptake, creating positive feedback.

normalized.interpretation: Minimum RH for hygroscopic growth contribution

relationships.source_quote: PM2.5 concentrations rose to over 400 μg m⁻³ during the high-RH period (Stage II) in concert with a rise in sulfate.

quantitative_evidence.description: PM2.5 increased from 210 μg/m³ to 330 μg/m³, sulfate increased 4x

relationships.notes: Direct mass contribution plus positive feedback through hygroscopicity

relationships.description: Intense solar radiation drives photolysis reactions producing oxidants
relationships.mechanism: Intense solar radiation (especially UV) drives photolysis reactions that produce hydroxyl radicals (OH) and other oxidants. These oxidants initiate the oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

normalized.interpretation: Clear sky allows maximum solar radiation

normalized.note: Can be proxied by solar_radiation intensity

relationships.source_quote: At lower pollution levels, the intense solar radiation caused substantial and rapid production of OOA (O/C = 0.81) and intermediate VOCs (both in a high oxidation state) at a rate of 15.0% h⁻¹ and 14.0% h⁻¹, respectively.

quantitative_evidence.description: OOA production rate 15.0% h⁻¹, intermediate VOCs at 14.0% h⁻¹

relationships.description: Photochemical oxidation of VOCs produces secondary organic aerosol
relationships.mechanism: Photochemical oxidation of VOCs by OH radicals produces low-volatility oxidized organic compounds that partition into the particle phase, forming secondary organic aerosol (SOA).

normalized.note: Different VOC types produce different SOA yields

relationships.source_quote: These results highlight the feedback effects between radiation and moisture in terms of altering the formation mechanism of secondary aerosols.

quantitative_evidence.description: Highly oxygenated OOA (O/C = 0.81) formed rapidly under strong solar radiation

relationships.notes: SOA formation rate depends on NOx regime (VOC-limited vs NOx-limited)

relationships.description: Clear sky conditions lead to higher PM2.5 than cloudy conditions
relationships.mechanism: Clear sky conditions enhance photochemistry and SOA formation. Additionally, clear sky is often associated with stagnant high-pressure systems that trap pollutants near the surface.

normalized.note: Can be proxied by pressure gradient or LTS
Low PBLH traps pollutants near surface

relationships.source_quote: In all regions, clear-sky PM2.5 concentrations are generally higher than cloudy with some exceptions during winter.

quantitative_evidence.description: Clear-sky PM2.5 generally higher than cloudy in all regions studied

relationships.notes: Winter may show exceptions due to different chemistry pathways

relationships.description: High RH triggers particle phase transition from semi-solid to liquid
relationships.mechanism: At RH above 40-60%, particles transition from semi-solid/solid state to liquid state. This occurs when aerosol liquid water (ALW) mass fraction exceeds 15% of dry mass.

normalized.interpretation: Phase transition RH threshold varies by particle composition
normalized.note: Lower bound for onset, upper bound for complete transition
ALW mass fraction threshold for phase transition

relationships.source_quote: A non-liquid to liquid phase transition occurs when the ALW mass fraction exceeds 15% (dry mass) at transition RH thresholds of 40%–60%.

quantitative_evidence.description: Phase transition at RH 40-60%, ALW > 15% of dry mass

relationships.notes: Phase transition is key trigger for positive feedback loop

relationships.description: Liquid particles enable faster heterogeneous and aqueous-phase reactions
relationships.mechanism: Liquid particles enable faster heterogeneous and aqueous-phase reactions. Gas-phase species can more easily partition into liquid particles and undergo aqueous-phase oxidation.
relationships.source_quote: The presence of abundant ALW, favored by elevated RH and higher proportion of SIA, facilitates the partitioning of water-soluble compounds from the gas to the particle phase.

quantitative_evidence.description: Sulfate and nitrate transformation rates increase by 48% and 11%

relationships.notes: Key step in positive feedback loop

relationships.description: Secondary aerosol production increases particle hygroscopicity
relationships.mechanism: Production of secondary inorganic aerosols (sulfate, nitrate) and oxidized organic aerosols increases particle hygroscopicity, enabling more water uptake.
relationships.source_quote: Consequently, the overall hygroscopicity parameters exhibit a substantial enhancement, with a mean value of 23%.
relationships.notes: Hygroscopic species: sulfate, nitrate, oxidized organics

relationships.description: More hygroscopic particles absorb more water, increasing ALW
relationships.mechanism: More hygroscopic particles absorb more water at the same RH, increasing aerosol liquid water content. This creates a positive feedback loop.

normalized.interpretation: Minimum RH for significant water uptake

relationships.source_quote: These results highlight phase transition as a key factor initiating the positive feedback loops between ALW and secondary aerosol formation during haze episodes.

quantitative_evidence.description: Positive feedback loop between ALW and secondary aerosol formation

relationships.notes: Completes the positive feedback loop: RH → phase transition → chemistry → hygroscopicity → ALW → more chemistry

causal_chains.name: Fog → Measurement Artifact Chain
causal_chains.description: Fog directly causes PM2.5 measurement overestimation in light-scattering sensors

causal_chains.name: Fog → Accelerated Chemistry → PM2.5 Chain
causal_chains.description: Fog enables rapid aqueous-phase chemistry that produces secondary aerosols, increasing actual PM2.5

causal_chains.name: Clear Sky → Photochemistry → SOA → PM2.5 Chain
causal_chains.description: Clear sky conditions enhance photochemistry, producing SOA that contributes to PM2.5

causal_chains.name: High RH → Phase Transition → Positive Feedback Chain
causal_chains.description: High RH triggers particle phase transition, enabling accelerated chemistry that increases hygroscopicity and ALW in a positive feedback loop

missing_info: UV index data source for photochemistry conditions; particle phase state direct measurement methods

key_findings: Fog droplets are detected as particles by light-scattering PM sensors, causing measurement artifacts (not actual pollution increase)
Fog and low clouds provide aqueous-phase reaction environment that accelerates sulfate formation by 0.5-1.3 μg m⁻³ h⁻¹, much faster than gas-phase pathways
Clear sky conditions can lead to higher PM2.5 than cloudy conditions due to enhanced photochemical SOA formation
High RH triggers particle phase transition that initiates positive feedback loops between aerosol liquid water and secondary aerosol formation
The distinction between measurement artifacts and actual pollution increase is critical for accurate air quality assessment
implications_for_hanoi: Hanoi's tropical humid climate with frequent fog events requires careful interpretation of PM2.5 sensor data
Winter monsoon cold surges bringing dry air followed by humid conditions can trigger rapid secondary aerosol formation
Clear sunny days in Hanoi can still have elevated PM2.5 due to photochemical SOA formation from traffic and industrial VOC emissions
Fog correction algorithms should be applied to light-scattering sensor data during fog events
